Award.AwardTitle: Mid-infrared molecular tags: a new palette for IR microscopy

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project develops a portfolio of molecular tags that emit strong signals when stimulated by mid-infrared (MIR) light. These molecular MIR tags are designed to light up selected parts in the cell when illuminated with an MIR microscope. The MIR tags developed by the investigators enable the visualization of molecular diffusion and chemical conversion, including numerous metabolic processes in cells and tissues, processes that have hitherto remained out of reach for MIR microscopy. This development transforms the MIR microscope from an instrument for inspecting static images of cells and tissue to a technology for studying dynamic processes such as cellular cholesterol uptake, protein synthesis and lipogenesis. This capability opens up new opportunities for investigating cellular processes that are difficult to study with standard optical microscopy methods. The investigators are committed to broaden the participation of a diverse pool of students by providing summer research training to students from HBCUs through the Access to Careers in Engineering and Sciences (ACES) program.

MIR imaging, typically in the form of Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) microscopy, is a label-free imaging tool based on molecular vibrational contrast. MIR labels or tags can significantly improve the specificity of MIR imaging, yet MIR labels have so far not been used for imaging purposes. The use of MIR labels would expand the complementary vibrational palette in IR microscopy, opening up a new catalogue of biorthogonal molecular probes based on IR transitions, and offering strategies for super-multiplex imaging. In this project, the PI and co-PI develop a portfolio of chemical motifs that exhibit an exceptionally strong IR-response. They will use these motifs as vibrational tags of small molecules, including cholesterol, glucose, nucleic acids, amino acids and other metabolites. In addition, the team will design probes suitable for fluorescence encoded infrared (FEIR) excitation and detection, enabling multiplex labeling studies in the MIR microscope with sensitivities that reach the single molecule limit.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To visualize biomolecular structures in cells in tissues, microscopists typically use fluorescent labels that selectively associate with the molecular target. Even though fluorescence microscopy has proven indispensable for scientific progress in cellular biology, there are many scenarios in which labeling is disruptive or even toxic to the specimen. Vibrational microscopy, on the other hand, makes it possible to map molecular structures in a label-free manner, as the signal derives from the intrinsic spectroscopic properties of the molecular targets. This label-free aspect renders vibrational microscopy a valuable tool in cellular biology, yet discriminating specific molecular structures from others can still be challenging in case spectroscopic features overlap. Vibrational tagging seeks to overcome this issue. Like fluorescent labeling, vibrational tagging allows high specificity for a particular molecular target. However, because vibrational tags are small, they are much less disruptive, and, unlike fluorescent labels, they are immune to photobleaching effects.

            The use of vibrational tags has significantly grown over the past decade, especially in the area of Raman microscopy. Raman tags are invariably based on the so-called alkyne motif, a chemical group consisting of two triple-bonded carbon atoms. Alkyne tags have a strong Raman response and their vibrational frequency (color) is distinct from that of common chemical groups that constitute most biomolecules, thus allowing sensitive detection free of background contributions. In this project, we improved the alkyne motif by linking it to a sulfur atom. This design strategy gives rise to an enormous boost of the tag’s Raman response. In addition, we dressed the alkyne mode with other chemical groups, allowing tuning of the tag’s color. The result is a palette of immensely strong and robust Raman tags that can be used for practical imaging applications.

            Infrared (IR) microscopy is another technique that allows vibrational imaging. However, unlike Raman microscopy, the use of tagging is less common in IR microscopy. One reason is that the versatile alkyne motif is not IR-active. To overcome this limitation, we applied chemical design strategies to turn the otherwise dark alkyne motif into a bright IR tag. To achieve this, we sandwiched the alkyne group between a sulfur and a silicon atom. The interaction of the alkyne moiety with both these atomic neighbors ‘switches on’ its IR-activity and allows its use as an IR-tag. In this project, we designed, synthesized, and tested several Si-based alkyne tags that show exceptional IR signals and are well tolerated by cells. 

            Taken together, this project has produced a series of versatile vibrational tags, both for Raman and IR microscopy. Given their robustness, it can be expected that these tags find important applications in the area of label-free biological imaging.
